snippet: Analysts placed blame for the increases on record exports, frigid winter weather and rains last year that led to higher demand from farmers.
abstract: Millions of Americans are struggling with shortage of propane, byproduct of natural gas production and crude oil refining, to heat their homes and keep their farms running; while fuel production is up 15 percent over a year ago, inventories are still nearly 50 percent lower than last winter, and many Southerners and Midwesterners who depend on the fuel are angry and confused.

byline.original: By ALAN BLINDER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
byline.contributor: Alan Blinder reported from Eastaboga, and Clifford Krauss from Houston. Christina Capecchi contributed reporting from Ryan, Iowa, and St. Paul, and Michael Avok from Madison, Neb.

lead_paragraph: Analysts placed blame for the increases on record exports, frigid winter weather and rains last year that led to higher demand from farmers.

headline.main: Too Much Winter, and Not Nearly Enough Propane
headline.print_headline: Too Much Winter, and Not Nearly Enough Propane
